review: This book. I want to  it so I can remember my feelings later, but I hardly know where to start. Wow! It actually took me years to finish readingThis book. I want to  it so I can remember my feelings later, but I hardly know where to start. Wow! It actually took me years to finish reading it. I can’t remember when or why I bought it, but occasionally I would pick it up and read a few pages or a chapter. It is challenging and requires concentration, and I am basically always some degree of tired, so I would lose focus or start falling asleep, but something kept drawing me back. The writing is beautiful. The characters are compelling. The situation is haunting. I’d leave it for months and then pick it back up and start to re-read it from the beginning to remember what I had read.Finally, recently, I picked up this book again and started making actual progress. It was still difficult. The jump in timelines can be confusing and I knew absolutely nothing about Chechnya and it’s history. By the end of chapter 12, about halfway through, I was so invested and entranced that I made the decision to start back at the beginning so I could catch and understand better the things I had missed. I also think I never really wanted to be finished. Before re-starting I read up a little bit on the First and Second Chechen Wars and the history of Chechnya. I made a timeline of significant events. Then as I read it again, I fit what was happening into that timeline, which helped a lot.It is a dark and painful story, filled with tragedy and some of the more despicable acts of humanity, with language and situations that certainly offend, but I felt it was balanced by acts of love, beauty, loyalty, sacrifice, hope, and life. The era covered (1994-2004) was a time of chaos, war, death, pain, loss, and betrayal, but the narrator was all-knowing and would give random little glimpses into a happier future, even for minor characters. It gave much needed hope that someday things would be better. For example:“The guard, thirty-one years old, had never received a paycheck, and wouldn’t have known what to do with one if he had; in three years, when the hospital issued paychecks again, beginning with a whopping nine years of back pay, the guard would frame his in glass and hang it on his wall without ever depositing it.”It was startling but comforting to see little hints that someday life would be normal again. People would get paid. The hospital that was practically in ruins would get back on its feet. Those little peeks into the future helped lighten the mood. I appreciated that touch. I finished reading this book in an hours-long session to the end the other day, filled with gasps, flinches, smiles, laughter, tears, even sobs. I told you I was invested.The strange title started to make sense in chapter 12. A character is looking at a medical dictionary. “She flipped through the book and found answers to questions no sane person would ever ask. The definition of a foot. The average length of a femur. Nothing for insanity by grief, or insanity by loneliness, or insanity by reading reference books. What inoculation could the eight-point font provide for the whisper of Sukhois in the sky? Based on the average life expectancy of a Soviet woman, she could expect to live for another forty-eight years, but the Soviet Union had died, and she hadn’t, and the appendices couldn’t explain this discrepancy in data, when the subject outlasted its experiment. Only one entry supplied an adequate definition, and she circled it with red ink, and referred to it nightly. Life: a constellation of vital phenomena—organization, irritability, movement, growth, reproduction, adaptation.”And that’s what you see in the characters. How they grow, move, and adapt to extreme circumstances. The choices they have to make. Life. The good, the bad, the beautiful, the ugly. It takes place in the South during the time of slavery, the end of 1700s and beginning I hardly know what to think of this book, which I listened to. It takes place in the South during the time of slavery, the end of 1700s and beginning of the 1800s. It certainly had a lot of good qualities. It was well written and very descriptive, with characters that I cared about and that felt real, but there were so many horrible things that happened that it was hard to take in. I would take long breaks from it, weeks or months, and then decide to give it another chance, and then traumatic things would just keep happening. At one point I thought I should just throw in the towel, but I told myself that if I’m going to be a nurse I have to learn to accept that really bad things happen to people and learn to hear and deal with those stories, although if it had been poorly written or completely without merit I would have given it up. At times things started to look up a little and I could sort of imagine some possible happiness and thought I had gotten through the worst of it, but alas there was plenty more horrible stuff ahead of me. At the end I felt like the author owed me more than she gave me in wrapping it up. It did soften me some to hear the author’s account of how this story came to her almost outside of herself and how emotionally draining it was to write. Sometimes she would try to change certain parts to not be so awful, but then she would get blocked and couldn’t move on from that point until she changed it back. That was interesting and I guess helps explain all the darkness. Slavery was dark. People can do unspeakable things to each other. Life can throw accidents and illnesses and all kinds of terrible things at you. I kind of knew those things and I’m not sure if it was educational or enlightening to be exposed to it all like that, but it does make me appreciate more what I have, the life that I live, the freedoms I have, and the people who love me and treat me well, so I guess that is one valuable reminder I can take from this book....more

It was kind of a perfect vacation book, mostly light and entertaining, but there were some interesting things to think about as well. The main character is a 39-year-old genetics professor with characteristics of Asperger's syndrome. In studying about Asperger's syndrome he says, "I formed a provisional conclusion that most of these [symptoms of Asperger's syndrome] were simply variations in human brain function that had been inappropriately medicalized because they did not fit social norms--constructed social norms--that reflected the most common human configurations rather than the full range." So there is a wide range of normal human behavior and we've decided to make a syndrome for those who are on the outskirts of normal. I see that point, but I also think it can be helpful to identify people that have these characteristics (or symptoms) so that they can get the extra help they need functioning in a very social world. I think identifying with a particular “syndrome” helps them see that there are others like them in the world. I liked when he said, “Asperger’s isn’t a fault. It’s a variant. It’s potentially a major advantage. Asperger’s syndrome is associated with organization, focus, innovative thinking, and rational detachment.” There was some good food for thought, but mostly this book wasn’t about Asperger’s syndrome. It was about a man who is very bright, very organized, very structured in his life and schedule, and very clueless and awkward socially, who decides he wants to find a wife and tries to go about it in a scientific way. There were some confusing or hard to believe aspects to the story, but overall it was funny, charming, sometimes quite touching, and satisfying. At some point I had just had enough of the story and couldn't motivate myself to keep going. "Three Cups of Deceit" refutes many of the stories in "Three Cups of Tea" and exposes Greg Mortenson as misusing charitable funds and failing to responsibly account for expenses. The author, Jon Krakauer, had been a previous supporter of Greg Mortenson's charity CAI and had donated money and time as a speaker to help with fundraising. He started to get wind of problems with leadership and use of funds, though, and withdrew his support and finally wrote this book to educate the public about the deception. I felt some of Krakauer's anger and betrayal coming through. I think he made a fairly strong case to support his point, but I think he could have been more balanced by describing more of the good that Mortensen accomplished. From my perspective he seems like a man with great talents, but also great flaws. He is disorganized and inconsistent, probably ADD. He is terrible about returning calls, keeping commitments, being on time, keeping track of expenses, etc. He is great about using his charisma to get things to happen and drumming up support. He dreams big and accomplishes a lot, but maybe not as much as he says or in exactly the way that he says. He seems to have a very flexible relationship with the truth. He let the admiration and success build up his ego and felt he could get away with whatever he wanted. I don't in any way excuse his actions, but I can see how it came about and how that personality works. I think his biggest mistake was not recognizing his own weaknesses and allowing others to help with the financial and organizational side of things, instead of brushing them off and failing to communicate. I think he should be held accountable for his actions and pay back any misused funds. I also hate deceit of any kind and the fact that he made up stories or embellished them or changed facts in a supposedly nonfiction book bothers me a lot. You want to be able to believe what you read, but unfortunately you have to take most things with a grain of salt. For me, I decided that regardless of the truth of some sections of "Three Cups of Tea" I can take the positive message of doing what I can to make a difference in the world and help other people. For example, when she describes at the beginning her feeling of coming back to the beach she says, At first, the tired body takes over completely. It was an act as careless and spontaneous as the curl of a stem or the kindling of a star.The mockingbird took a single step into the air and dropped. In that first chapter I saw some behaviors and attitudes in the husband, Carl, that concerned me, so I thought I had it all worked out. They were going to have a very difficult marriage, probably ending unhappily, representing the weeping in the night, and then joy would come in the morning with some kind of happy ending where Annie moves on stronger into a new life. Well, hopefully it's not a spoiler to say that I was completely wrong about the plot. It was more about defying expectations and working through challenges, coming out stronger, which is very good but I just kept being thrown off by what I expected. I also kept getting thrown out of the story because of Annie's interest in reading and writing. I couldn't help but wonder how much was based on the author's life and if she had had some of the same experiences. At one point she writes a little play based on a conversation with Carl, but the outcome is completely different in the way he reacts to things she says and the way the scene ends. I found that really interesting because that is probably what the author does. She takes things from her own life and then changes them to be the way she wished they had been or to be more interesting. So really I think most of the problems I had with it were my own fault, my expectations and my pulling out of the story to analyze and wonder about the author. I do think that even without me doing that, it is not as good of a story as A Tree Grows in Brooklyn. It doesn't have the same scope. "The Age of Innocence" is the kind of book I read slowly, enjoying the language and the thoughts and just sort of immersing into that time. "The Help" was much more of a modern, quick, plot-driven read, the kind of book that I don't want to put down and I stay up late reading to see what happens. I loved both. It wasn't until late in "The Help" that the similarities in the stories occurred to me, though. They are both talking about the small, closed, rich white society where anyone different is an outcast. In "The Age of Innocence" it's back in 1800s New York City, rejecting those like Ellen who don't fit their narrow view of behavior and propriety. In "The Help" it's in 1960's Mississippi, where black people are treated as not quite people and among white people, those that don't fit their ideas of proper dress, behavior, or thinking are shunned and outcast in much the same way they were in "The Age of Innocence." Reading this book, I was reminded of the quote that came up in book club last month by Eleanor Roosevelt: "Great minds discuss ideas; avereage minds discuss events; small minds discuss people."After reading "The Age of Innocence" I was a little bit sympathetic to Newland Archer, not completely, but I wasn't too harsh on his choices. I think Miss Skeeter is the Newland Archer of "The Help" and somehow after reading about how she handled being in a similar position as Newland, (on the inside of this closed group, but feeling the pull of more openness and freedom of thought and behavior), I actually look back at Newland and judge him more harshly now. I see how untrue he was being to himself. He was hiding his true thoughts and feelings from those closest to him and he really was living kind of a fake life, even though he did experience some happiness from it. He never had the courage to really live the way he wanted to. Miss Skeeter eventually accepted the consequences of her different viewpoints and allowed herself to be an outcast rather than bend to the ideas of the group. Later when she imagines the life she could have had, there are good things, but overall she thinks she would have felt frustrated, which I think is how Newland felt in the life he chose.Comparisons aside, I think this was a well-written and interesting book. I enjoyed the characters. I had a hard time putting it down. I felt the author did a pretty good job with the different voices, maybe not quite as good as "The Poisonwood Bible" for example, but pretty good. It was interesting seeing the different points of view and I liked reading about the different character interactions. The book introduced me to a period of time, attitudes, and part of the country that was interesting for me to learn more about. Overall, just a really great book! How would I cope, coming from my life of comfort and plenty, if I had to live in extreme hunger and danger from the natural world? Why are there so many books where the preacher/religious person is the bad guy? How do you worship creation and ignore the creator? How do you reconcile all the bad things that have been done in the name of religion? Would it really have been better for Africa if they had been left to themselves, or how could things have been different? Obviously their natural resources shouldn't have been exploited and they shouldn't have been taken into slavery and all the evil things that happened, but isn't there something in the middle that could have happened rather than just leaving them in the state they were forever? Isn't there anything good about trying to bring them a higher standard of living and sharing faith and religion?
